name: Nidhogg
description: Nidhogg is the epic award-winning fencing tug-of-war, full of graceful acrobatics and clumsy stabs. IRL yelling and excitement may occur, in this ultimate two-player showdown of fast-paced fencing and melee attacks. Beware, advantages in Nidhogg are often fleeting, as new opponents continually spawn in your way.

My first online match had me cackling with glee. Fast paced fencing! You can change from low, mid, high stances plus you can hold up to throw your sword in a last ditch effort. You win a round and then try to advance screens in your direction so if you want to try to avoid combat after you win a round you can be a coward and beeline for the finish. Ok, enough typing, I have fast paced fencing to get to.

Nidhogg is great, simple to learn and a lot of fun. You will be shouting frantically at your opponent as you play, and it's a great game to bust out at parties/social gatherings. My girlfriend (who barely plays video games) was able to pick this up and we had a ton of fun with it.

It's like a low-fi, super simplifird smash brothers with some interesting independent elements that are born of the swordfighting theme. There's a lot that can be said about a simple engine that produces complex situations and gives such a wide flexibility to gameplay. It's one of those games that when you win or lose you never feel cheated and it's fun to end a match on either side of the divide.  I would say however that the price seems a little insane for the small amount of content, however if that's the price you pay for such a fittingly simple and robust online facility and touch perfect controls then I can understand even if I don't agree. The game really needs some free updates to it, perhaps even workshop level-editing. This really does feel like a proof of concept, albeit a really, really good one.

Nidhogg is a small game developed by an indie developer Messhof. While the game isn’t the longest one I have ever played, it is definitely THE best local multiplayer game I have played in a long time. You can literally spend countless hours playing the local multiplayer against your friends.  In Nidhogg there is only one objective , kill your opponent by out-stabbing them by using only three sets of stances, high, middle and low. Maneuvers such as, rolling, dive-kicking, neck-snapping and sword-throwing are also at your disposal. While it may sound simple at first, the game is really hard to master, and sometimes it gets a little bit frustrating when you get stabbed couple times in a row.  After you kill your enemy you have to run to the right in order to advance to next level, the enemy can do the same thing, if you get killed, he can run to the opposite direction, this will get you back to the previous screen, and this gets really annoying because sometimes the enemy instead of fighting you, will just run past you just to get you back to the previous screen. Each ‘level’ is divided into couple smaller ones. In single player, there is a total of 17 AI opponents, the first one being the easiest and the last one, the toughest(I don’t know if that’s true but when I’ve played it, the game got harder every time with each AI opponent). At the end of each level your character is eaten by a giant dragon-like creature, by the name of Nidhogg, you can’t avoid it though(trust me, I’ve tried), I don’t know what’s the point of that but It’s kind of hilarious and random.  The art style is what I love the most about this game, it has that surreal look to it, kind of like Hotline Miami. The player animations are also worth mentioning because of how smooth and realistic they are, and also it feels really satisfying when you stab someone.  On the other hand, the game also has some flaws, one of them is the online multiplayer, it is seriously lacking in features and is very unstable, I kept being disconnected from matches, and I have experienced serious lag during several online matches. You can’t even properly communicate with your opponent because the chat can’t handle longer messages.  As I have said before, the single-player consists of 17 AI opponents, which is great but the same can’t be said about the level variety, there is only 3 or 4 different levels which are re-used during the 17 battles in the single-player. I really wish that there was more variety in level design, maybe we’ll get them in later updates.  Nonetheless, If you enjoy playing games with your friends then this game is for you but If you don’t like the local multiplayer I would still recommend sure the game isn’t very long, but the multiplayer is still there, it might be a bit lackluster but who knows maybe the devs will add some new features to the online multiplayer.

THE NIDHOGG MUST FEED. A SNACKRIFICE AWAITS. The question is, will it be you, or the other guy? Nidhogg is ostensibly a fencing game. But this appraisal is kind of misleading; it's definitely a game that features fencing, and the fencing is both simple and intense in the way many early-era 2 player games were (like Swashbuckler and Championship Karate). But there are a number of things going on here that you wouldn't see anybody getting away with in a proper fencing match, and that's where things start getting interesting. Throwing swords, sweeping the leg, and jump kicking the other dude in the chest are among the other tricks the Yellow Swoardsman and Orange Swordsman have at their disposal. But wait; the match isn't won when your enemy's body is at your feet. Victory is only achieved by reaching the end of the level, far past your nemesis' starting position. And you'll find several more of him waiting where the first one came from. So it's like fencing, even when it contains things other than fencing. Nidhogg is a must-play for anyone with a friend to play with, or hell, train your cat extremely well and play it with him.

I strongly recommend this game. Even with the people complaining about lag in the forums, I played it with my friend and had no problems at all. And being a huge fencing fan, I think this game is perfect in the format it was made. You really need to approach the fight strategically or you'll get your derrière sistematically handed to you. The game is one hit kill when armed with sword and when disarmed if your opponent strikes you on the ground he'll snap your neck and kill you, but this is just a mean to an end, since your main goal ain't to kill your opponent but to get to the last screen you need to push to be devoured by the mythical serpent Nidhogg, hence the name of the game, and to do that you need to kill you enemy and move forward through each screen, being lead to a fence-fueled tug of war. And the graphics, soundtrack and sound effects match the game perfectly and until now I didn't experienced any major flaws on the gameplay of the game which is fluid and easy to get the hang. The single-player can be fun enough, but the game really shines in the multiplayer, the local versus can make for a really neat party game. So scrap some cash and buy this gem.

The adrenaline will fly as you try to overtake your opponent in Nidhogg! The object of the game is to reach the other side of the map, to which there are seven sections; the only thing stopping you is your little set of legs and your adversary. There is a surprising amount of depth to this one on one side scroller, despite the only controls being jump, attack and the directions. You can hold your sword in three positions: high, medium, or low. Where you hold the sword dictates what attacks you will block.    All throughout you will have to make split-second decisions, and those decisions are what make the game so addicting. At times, you will be convinced that you have felled the enemy, only to be rolled into and killed. These are the defining moments of Nidhogg; while your jaw is on the floor from the surprise, your stinker of a roommate hoofs it to the goal.

Oooh, this is a clever little game we have here that essentially covers a 9 stage long map focusing on fencing and running for your life. Nidhogg is a tug-of-war game that relies on basic movement and attack mechanics (literally, there are 6 controls) to simulate fast-paced fencing and brawling combat in a race to be devoured by the beast called, 'Nidhogg'. While the end result of winning is less than appealing the gameplay itself is very clever, as players are constantly able to change their way of playing to adapt to their opponent's play style, and the cute graphical style while sometimes can be an eyesore (prime example being the pre-game chat, it's basically impossible to tell the letters apart.), it usually has this sort of retro charm that makes you want to wash the floors with your opponents blood once more. So, do I reccomend this game? Yes. Will I continue to play it for years to come? Yes.  -WolfEpiphany

Nidhogg is perfect example that fighting games can offer more variety than what most of its competition would lead to believe.  The game is ultimately a game of tag with the objective being to run to your goal. You become 'it' when you defeat your opponent or they suicide. Whenever you die or trail off-screen, you will generally respawn in your opponent's path a few moments later. When you spawn, you are given a fencing sword to use in combat with the other player, but you can also fight unarmed if you throw your sword or you can also pick-up a sword dropped earlier on that section of the stage map. There is a decent variety of options that are simplistic in execution but add a lot of depth to the game, especially when used in conjunction with the terrain of the stage.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys versus multiplayer games, not just fans of the fighting game genre.

Reminiscent of (the original) Prince of Persia sword fights; only much faster and with versus multiplayer. Don't let it's simple concept and graphics fool you, this game is unbelievably fun. Nidhogg is a great example of mechanics (gameplay) over aesthetics (graphics), proving that being FUN TO PLAY is the single most important part of game design; these developers could teach Square Enix a thing or two... but don't get me started on that old chestnut.

Nidhogg is a rare title that has an even more unique popularity. It's the kind of game that has been more likely spread via word-of-mouth than anything. And for good reason, it's a fantastic game. Now, on the surface you might see pictures and think: ''Well, damn. This looks very basic, very retro -- I can't gouge out if the gameplay is good or not!'' But once you so much as take at let's play videos or even a few trailers, it becomes immediately apparent that this game - Nidhogg - is 100% unfilitered crazy gameplay.  In a nutshell, it's an extreme tug-of-war situation with fighting mechanics very similar to Joust, old school Prince of Persia and even a few beloved flash game titles like the XiaoXiao games and animations. Players are welcomed right off the bat with a very clean, very informative tutorial that teaches them how to fence, how to thrust, how to divekick and how to NIDHOGG.  There's 4 levels and an arcade ladder with a time attack incentive. So, you're wondering how the multiplayer is, right? The game looks and plays amazing but how will it fare for you and your online buddies? Well. Not very good. Every game has it's flaw, and unfortunately Nidhogg has an extremely flawed netcode. That is to say, it's more than lag. It's actually client/host biased. Depending on who is the host determines who gets a seamless performance, if you're the client, then you will experience the worst latency and detection possible. It's unplayable.  I have hope this will be fixed in the future, however. Nidhogg cost me around £12, like $20 in US. It would have been worth the asking price if (and only if) the online multiplayer was fixed. My final advice: If you plan on playing with friends over a few beers in real? Buy it. If you plan on playing over skype with buddies across the world? You may want to wait a while.

Nighogg is one of the tensest and most easily accesible game I've played in years. The controls are simple and tight, and both players are on perfectly even ground. I have played matches with both friends as well as the CPU's, and they have varied in length from 20 seconds to 20 minutes on the same map. There is never a match where you aren't completely conentrating on winning, and you must utilize the few mechanics there are to achieve that victory. It is some of the best sword-play I have seen in any game, and you will hoot or holler at least once when you play with friends. There are only a few maps, and there's only one that can be considered 'Final Destination' level of even playing ground, as the few others have some sort of unique obstacles that clash with the core gameplay, but they all provide a slight and welcome variation in the same experiece. I've also had a bit of trouble getting matches to connect when trying to play online, but I'd hazard a guess and say it's because not that many people are trying to play online, so I can't reall call that a point against the game. Whatever little quibbles I have, the point I'm trying to make here is that if you need a game for one-on-one time with your pals, Nidhogg is one of the easiest to pick and most fun games you can find in that category.

This game is great. Ridiculously simple, yet deceptively challenging, Nidhogg provides an experience like no other: the thrill of stabbing your silhouette-man opponent in the face so you can get eaten by a giant worm... thing.  Seriously though, the game is very good. I've seen virtually no fencing games, so this game is in a very small category, but it does capture the feel of a sword duel very well; the waiting, positioning your sword for an advantage, looking for an opening to strike like lightning. I would know; I'm a fencer.  The controls are quite simple, but there is a lot you can do with those six buttons. The tug-of-war mechanic is pretty clever, and adds a nice level of tension to the swordplay. If you screw up, your opponent could make a straight run to the end, virtually unopposed.  The graphics are not impressive, but that should be obvious from the screenshots. The art style is interesting enough, if not terribly complex. However, the main focus of the game is the swordplay, so the visuals are not important in the slightest. in fact, something more realistic might actually detract from the experience.  All in all, Nidhogg is a very good game. Definitely a solid 8 impalings out of 10. I personally think it's worth the $14.99. I've spent that much to see a two-hour movie, and this game can easily give me much more entertainment value for at least that long. Probably longer. I highly recommend this game.

This game is fantastic. It brings back not just the nostalgia of playing heated matches with your friends on the couch, but also the pure skill and difficulty to truly master the game. This is not something that will give you instant gratification while holding your hand the whole way, like most games that are released nowadays seem to do, and yet anyone can pick it up and play it within minutes.   It has to be said that those who bought this game expecting a single-player experience, or a game with a lot of combos and superficial depth, are going to be disappointed. Since the beginning of development, the game was, in my opinion, clearly focused on local multiplayer. This was meant to be a party game, or something that you and your friends could enjoy giving each other grief over on those late nights. I am pretty old school, and have gotten weary of the online matchmaking systems that most games implement - you just can't be certain you will be paired with someone that will make the game enjoyable for you. If you really want to have fun, you should be playing with your real friends anyways. And if that's your opinion on gaming as well, do yourself and your friends a favor - buy this game. It is absolutely worth it.

Nidhogg is a great multiplayer game, but it may likely only be worth it for you if you have a friend who can play it with you in person, the online is broken and nearly dead. The single player can help you learn the basics of combat, and can be a refreshing way to just fool around for a few minutes whenever you feel like it, but the meat of the game is in multiplayer, and right now the online feels dead and lags too much to enjoy consistant fair matches.  Nidhogg's gameplay is fast paced, fair, and rewards creativity and skill. You will probably enjoy how the match goes too much to have hard feelings over winning or losing. Each match is played on one of 4 stages, each with 5 screens, one neutral screen and two screens for each player. Each player has an unlimited stock of lives, the goal isn't to kill your opponent but to reach the end of your opponent's last screen, killing them simply makes it harder for them to stop you.  There is no skill floor or base APM that you need to meet to compete, no ganking or equipment advantage in Nidhogg, each player has only their foil and their wits as tools to reach their goal. Many times you may lose to an opponent only to find yourself learning a new technique or tactic to add to your toolbox, making playing against a more skilled opponent a much less daunting experience than in other games. Roping your friends in to play with you as your opponent doesn't feel like a chore or unreachable task if they have no knowledge base or skill in the genre, since they will pick up very quickly on the intuitive controls and learn how to play from simple observation.  TLDR: Nidhogg is a game that feels perfectly easy to play and difficult to master, but at the same time avoids many problems of more hardcore dedicated multiplayer games that have the same strengths, and never comes off as unfair or unfun. If you have a friend to play against, or can nab Nidhogg in a sale I strongly recommend trying it. The game is bare bones, but the gameplay itself is fantastic and intuitive.

Don't let the graphics decieve you into thinking this is an inferior game. This is actually one of the best one-on-one multiplayer games and makes for some intensely entertaining matches. The graphics just drive the point that the gameplay is simple and could have, indeed have been done several years ago. The type of game that makes you say 'why hasn't anyone done this before?' This is one of the simplest controls in a fighting-style game, yet despite its simplicity there is a lot of depth and split second strategy involved. It's easy to see what your opponent did and say 'Oh, now I know I can do that next time' without thinking which button to press. This is like a Versus fighting / sidescroller where both opponents start in the middle and try to fight / run their way to their victory side. Like American Football one team is able to proceed at a time while the other acts on defense to keep you from moving forward. A kill means you can go forward to your goal. You're in the constant frontline of a battle between yellow and orange. Do you go in slowly picking out each of your opponents one by one? Or did you see an opportunity to throw your sword and dash like hell to the next screen? High, medium, and low sword attacks for poking (lower goes furthest) move your sword between the three positions with up/down keys, switching position to an attacking sword parrys it away. You can roll underneath a mid-high sword while low sword pokes a rolling opponent in the eye. You can jump and divekick your opponent to make them drop their sword, while they can throw their sword at you for an easy in-air hit. Thrown swords can be blocked in mid and high position... Very simple in motion and with an answer to everything a very well balanced breakfast. I give it 5 stars.

When I first heard about Nidhogg, it sounded like a dream. There were whispers in multipayer communities about a rise of local multiplayer games that truly captured the imagination. The rise of games like Samurai Gunn and Towerfall Ascension have been popping up in the gaming scene, and it has been much better for it. Nidhogg, much like the aformentioned titles, offers that same sort of experience to players.  Nidhogg could be describe as a combat simulator, but of the flashy variety. It offers various levels of play with a basic control scheme. At first glance the game seems a little lacking in levels, but once you dive in the game reveals it's levels of depth. In some regards it seems similar to the high level of play found in a Smash Bros Melee game. Some levels provide a 'gimmick' to playing them, as others offer simplicity. The Stages, Castle and Mines, offer the most straightforward approach to combat, while other levels lik Clouds and Wilds offer more strategic play for more wilely players.  When picking up the game, it's important to ask why you're doing it. This is not for the solitary experience, certainly not worth the price point. Get some friends together and have yourself a classic gaming night.

Nidhogg's multiplayer is the kind of game that should be played on a movie screen or by Fred Savage in The Wizard. It is one of those perfect little games that you could just play over and over and over and laugh as you skewer your friends or rip their face off(?!).   All that being said....I wish there was a bit more to the game. There are only 4 levels to fight on and a pretty barebones options screen. If this game was beefed up a little bit, it would be one of the most popular and timeless multiplayer games ever made.

GOOD:  - the best party game ever made - offers great facility for local play - quick, addictive action of the 'just one more match, I'll show you this time' kind - this game is as fun to watch others play as it is to play it yourself - simple controls (directions + 2 keys), yet the gamplay isn't shallow/simple at all, even against the AI - minimalist, aesthetically pleasing graphics that really make the game easy to follow - the MODES the game has for local 1v1 are insanely fun and can be stacked/combined, i.e. turbo speed, slow motion speed, no weapons mode, no dive kick mode, players leave multicolored traces mode etc etc.  BAD:  - forget about playing this game over the network, not only no one is ever available when you try the matchmaking, but also due to the quick nature of the game any latency is gamebreaking - too few maps to fight on  OVERALL:  If you have friends/roommates/anyone with whom you can play often locally, get the game by all means. If not you will mostly be left playing against the AI, which is OK but not nearly as fun as stomping your friends in local 1v1.

Want a fun little game where the pure aim is to stab your friends repeatedly and run to the other side of the map? Then this is the game for you!  Pros:  The game is fun, fast paced, keeps you on your toes, music is perfect for the game and comedic moments are never far behind.  Cons: It's very limited, you fight your way to the other side of the map then rinse and repeat. Matchmaking is terrible it takes too long to find an opponent unless you are playing against friends, this is primarily due to the fact that having very little to do in the game results in short play times and once you've done it there's really no need to go back.  Overall: It's not really worth the money for what it is. It's very fun but the fun will soon run out. I would only recommend it if you have the money to spend on it for only a couple hours of fun.

Fun game, but absolutely infuriating. The gameplay is innovative and complicated, but it basically goes to waste because of the glaring flaws in its mechanics. It is far too easy to simply run past your opponent and prevent them from attacking you. All you have to do is evade their attacks when the arrow is on you and you can skip right to the end. You can also cheap-shot them if their sword isn't in the right place, making it even harder for a defender to turn the tide. It's advertised as a fencing game but it's really about trolling. If you want to get good at this strategy and use it to ♥♥♥♥ off everyone you play against, absolutely, buy this game. dont buy this game. its not worth 15 dollars. 10, maybe, but probably more like 5. The controls are screwed up to the point were its incredibly hard to control your guy. The mechanics allow your enemy to stab you from the exact same distance you TRIED to stab him. In fact, overall the mechanic where you NEED to be doing a specific action (in this case, sprint and duck/up) to either throw your sword, or do a leg sweep, is stupid, and only has a chance to work. I have died so many times as I have attempted to perform a sword throw, and rather have just raised my sword stupidly. additionally, the game system itself is flawed. Nidhogg uses a system called right of way to determin the winner. This means that when someone kills the other, they can just continuosly run to the endzone of the level, winning. Only one person can have right of way, but the person without spawns in front of the person with right of way whenever they die. First of all, this system is broken, as whoever has right of way can just jump over the enemy whenever they spawn. The spawning itself is flawed too, as you will find yourself having to kill someone three times just to move five feet, because they respawn the second after you kill them. These game mechanics arent broken, they just make the game frustrating rather than fun. Overall, this game is like a math test, it tests for skill, certainly, but its never fun, ever.

I grabbed this game during the Steam summer sale for about three dollars, and it was well worth the price. That's not a compliment - this game is three dollars worth of fun, now at five times the worthy cost.  It might be more fun if there was an online community, but there isn't, or at least there wasn't when I was playing.  Overall it's a decent game. Fairly fun. The basic idea is that you get to flip, jump, and run around like a normal platformer, with the added bonus of having to fence/fist-fight enemies. Once you kill an enemy, you can start running towards the end goal. If an enemy kills you, HE can run towards the end goal. Whoever dies gets to respawn and try to stop the other from getting there, but the guy running can literally jump over you and keep going. It takes a bit of skill and getting used to, but when you pick up the controls and start really understanding things, you'll get the hang of it.   Again, it's a decent game, it's just not worth fifteen dollars. Maybe if there were more people to play online with, or there were more stages, characters, or weapons, but there's only about four or five stages (if even that many), one type of weapon (not counting hand-to-hand), and there's only the one character (you can't even choose your color). So, all in all, it's just not worth it.

Unfortunately the online is bad. It is hard to find anyone else playing, and when you do get a match, most likely lag will happen. From my experience the lag isn't the same for both people playing. One person could be lagging out and the other has a perfectly smooth experience. This game can't fall on a single player experience either. This type of game loses much of its satisfaction with lifeless opponents.

Nidhogg is somewhat interesting, but not amazing at all.  It's price is far too much to make up for what's in the game. Online multiplayer is extremely broken, and the single player mode isn't very good, as they get to an unfair level of difficulty. The fighting feels really random as well. I've put roughly 30 minutes in to the game and I've seen all it has to offer, and I can't say I was too happy with any of it.  It does however somewhat well in local multiplayer though, so it offers a bit of fun here and there. It is very fast-paced, so if you don't mind a bit of glitchy fighting, and fast paced action, this would probably be for you. I however was looking for something that had a bit more content, and this didn't deliver.  While it's a fun idea, it was executed very poorly.
A vary fun game, but I can recommend it at its price. Buy it at a discount of you want it.

This game is a lot of fun, but I can't say I would buy it for anything more than 5 or 6 CDN, and even then that's pushing it. I was lucky enough to receive this as a gift, and I absolutely love the versus mode, however it does seem to get a bit buggy at times-- like other reviewers have pointed out. The single-player mode is alright, though the same handful of environments from the versus mode are recycled here, and the music is the same as well. I personally think that a game being sold for this much money should have at least a bit more to it than a few environments and 2 game modes.. I'd wait for it to go on sale.  TL;DR this game is a lot of fun (especially with friends) but the pricing is a bit excessive, so for that reason I can't recommend buying this unless it's on sale or part of a bundle.

Update: I originally rated this game positively, but since then there have been no updates to address the terrible lag in my favorite part of the game: multiplayer. And there is no word of the developers working on any extra maps leaving the game with only four maps and terrible multiplayer. Not happy. Until the developers fix this unplayable multiplayer lag and add more maps I wouldn't recommend this game.  Original Review: This game is REALLY fun! If you like platforming games and have a friend to play with, you will have hours of fun at a time. I've only played multiplayer with my friend so far so I have no comment on the single player but I bet it is equally as fun. I got it from a humble bundle (you only need to pay $1 on Humble to get this game along with two other fun games), and I am very happy with my purchase. I'm glad that I got a bunch of fun games and donated to charity all at the same time! My only complaint with this game is that it will occasionally lag in multiplayer, and will very rarely glitch my opponent one one screen closer to the winning screen sometimes. This is definitely not an issue with my very powerful PC or speedy internet, so I'm guessing it's just a bug that will likely be fixed. I highly recommend this game if you have friends. PS. It would be awesome if new maps are added on to the base game later in development to give it more variety. And just a pet peve of mine, it would also be nice if the game ran in full 16/9 ratio so I dont have the black bars at the edges of my screen
